Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Conservation Engineering and Cross-Slope Terracing in Mexico

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Imitating the works of ancient and native peoples, federal conservation agencies in Mexico build earthen terraces on mountain slopes to capture surface runoff, inhibit erosion, and improve water infiltration into agricultural soils. Doctoral student Matthew LaFevor under the guidance of Professor William Doolittle in the Department of Geography at the University of Texas at Austin will investigate one of these terracing methods, zanja-bordo, for its effectiveness at conserving water and increasing soil moisture levels in agricultural fields of northern Tlaxcala. The impetus for the research is to better understand the mechanics of, and investments in, indigenous water management technologies as mitigation strategies at times of freshwater deficits in the context of climate change. This study will entail volumetric soil moisture sampling and mapping of zanja-bordo terraces, as well as semi-structured interviews with terrace farmers and federal conservation officials. Estimating the moisture levels of both zanja-bordo and control plots, over specific spatial scales, will provide valuable data that will be used to test existing assumptions over their hydrological benefits. Spatial measurements of zanja-bordo terraces in the field will allow for their comparison with the architectural forms specified in the federal design templates used to build them. Variations between these more theoretical design models and actual field measurements would have implications for the long-term effectiveness of terracing projects. Finally, interviews with terrace builders and conservation officials will lend insight into the labor demands, required maintenance and sustainability of zanja-bordo terracing projects.

This field study will provide a critical assessment of one of Mexico's major environmental development initiatives. If shown to be effective, zanja-bordo techniques could be used to conserve freshwater resources, increase agricultural productivity, and improve the livelihoods of smallholder farmers in arid and semi-arid regions around the world. More globally, this research will offer a critical perspective on the effectiveness of using indigenous agricultural technologies for modern conservation practices, and it will advance knowledge about water harvesting techniques and the rain-fed agricultural systems upon which many subsistence communities depend. Results of this study will could improve governmental terracing projects that directly affect over 750,000 farmers in rural areas of Mexico by providing critical information and direction for environmental policy-making. The project?s collaborative focus will serve as a conduit for increased communication between conservation officials and local communities, many of which are composed of indigenous groups. Finally, the publication of findings in both U.S. and international journals will broaden interest in human-environment geography.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Conservation Engineering and Cross-Slope Terraceing in Mexico

In Mexico, conservation agencies build earthen terraces on mountain slopes to limit erosion, capture surface runoff, and improve water infiltration into agricultural soils. This project investigated one of these terrace types, zanja-bordo terraces, for its effectiveness at conserving water and increasing soil moisture levels in the agricultural fields of northern Tlaxcala. Although popularized by environmental groups as an effective method of water conservation, little is actually understood about how zanja-bordo terraces function.

The impetus for the research was threefold: (1) global climate change studies underscore the need for research on indigenous water management technologies, such as zanja-bordo terracing, as possible mitigation strategies against future hydrologic uncertainties; (2) although probably the most widespread form of agricultural slope management on the Mesa Central, the mechanics of zanja-bordo systems are not well understood; and (3) from 2001-2006 the Mexican government spent approximately 3.1 billion pesos (209 million USD) on terracing projects that covered about 1.7 million hectares of land (SAGARPA 2006). This represented a major environmental modification that warranted critical review. 

The project’s research design included building an experimental plot on 120 square meters of farmland in Tlaxcala. One half of the plot was built using zanja-bordo terraces with check dams (conservation method) and the second half was built without check dams (traditional method). Thirty soil moisture sensors were installed at various depths and across different architectural components of each of the terrace forms. The sensors logged moisture at five-minute increments for five months of the rainy season. In addition to the moisture measurements, runoff was collected in terrace ditches and analyzed. Results show that the terrace designs recommended by conservation groups (with check dams) provided soils with greater moisture retention and erosion mitigation, especially around their catchment areas. Results confirm that existing assumptions about the design criteria and environmental benefits of conservation terrace building are warranted.  

However, surveys of federal terrace construction projects using a total station and satellite imagery were incorporated into a GIS and analyzed against environmental factors and the design templates supposedly used to build them. Analysis revealed a wide range of actual terrace designs and maintenance practices among both federal construction projects and traditional terrace farmers. Interviews with farmers and conservation officials show that terrace designs are chosen for a variety of reasons, ranging from aesthetic considerations and cultural preferences to environmental and economic concerns. In short, terrace building for agriculture (form and function) does not always coincide with the terrace building of federal conservation programs. In the case of terrace farming in Tlaxcala, agricultural practice is not always “conservationist” in terms of maximizing water retention and mitigating runoff.   

This study: (1) offers a critical perspective on the effectiveness of using indigenous agricultural technologies for modern conservation practices; (2) adds to the limited, yet often-cited corpus of work on zanja-bordo mechanical form and function; (3) advances research on water harvesting techniques and the rain-fed agricultural systems upon which many subsistence communities depend; and (4) provides an essential analysis of the effectiveness of one form of terracing as a means of combating the hydrologic uncertainties of global climate change.
